Award.AwardTitle: "Targeted Infusion - Academic Enhancement of Biology Degree Program at Saint Augustine's College"

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of the targeted infusion project at Saint Augustine's College is to increase the number of STEM majors that complete the baccalaureate degree and matriculate into graduate degree programs in these fields. There is a special emphasis on plant biology and environmental science, two disciplines where diverse students are grossly underrepresented. By exposing Biology undergraduate majors to courses and career opportunities in plant biotechnology and environmental science, as well as strengthening student preparation for the rigor of graduate study, the institution expects to contribute to diversifying the US STEM workforce in a meaningful way. Specifically, the project will provide for curriculum additions and revisions beyond the traditional emphasis on biological processes. The project will also support modernization of laboratory equipment and research internships for students at partnering research intensive institutions. Collectively, these interventions have the potential to yield significant outcomes that can be easily transferable to similar institution types.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to increase the number of Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathmatics (STEM) majors who obtained baccalaureate degress with some knowledge of the field of environmental science. The primary focus of this project was to expand the exposure of biology majors to the field of environmental science by adding a new course and accompanying laboratory to the current Biology Degree Program. The intent was to further revise and enhance the biology degree program using this course as a platform to increse the number of STEM graduates who go on to graduate school and the workforce in the environmental sciences.

     During the project period of the grant, the new course BIOL 210- Environmental Science was approved and to date, has been taught twice. Although no textbook is currently required for the course, two text books, Principles of Environmental Science, Inquiry & Applications and Envirionmental Science, A Study of Interrelationships are used as resorces and supplemental readings. The instruction and learning format for the corse includes using a series of eductaional DVDs from the public Television Series Journey to Planet Earth as the primary platform for homework assignments, discussion and dialogue. A number of topics are covered during discussions including ennvironmetal conservation (water, soil, & Energy), food & agriculture, environmental health & toxicology, climate change, air & water polution, population control, economic & urbanization, and more current topics such as fracking & green initiatives. Most of the discussion topics are centered on major historic events coupled with current (BP oil spill, global warning-greenhouse effects, Michigan water contamination crisis, etc.) impactful events.

     As part of the laboratory portion of the course, Saint Augustine's University (SAU) has enhanced and continued its ongoing relationship with the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences & Nature Research Center in downtown, Raleigh, NC (~1.5 miles). Students are matched with Museum Scientist Advisors that guide their individual research/science enrichment project. At the end of the semester, students present their project as part of the laboratory requirement. Students are particularly fond of the laboratory format and the hands-on inquiry-based learning. This format allows students to interact directly with the general public, especially the K-12 students that visit the museum! Students indicate that this is one of the highlights of the course and several have continued working with the museum.

     In an effort to provide research exposure in environmental science, for the past few summers SAU students have participated in summer research internships, many of which are NSF sponsored REU programs. Locations for these internships have been as close as the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences in nearby RTP, NC and as far away as the Center for Dark Energy Biosphere Investigations, Global Enviornmental Microbiology Short Course at the University of Sourthern California. Partnerships with other environmental science-related laboratories are currently being established. As part of our ongoing Science Seminar Series, sevral scientists have served as invited speakers, many of which included some environmental theme within their respective presentations.
